And you heard what was being said in Europe yesterday about this being the only possible deal.“I think people need to focus on that.”

title: life sized replica noahs ark sail israel
story: One major hurdle to overcome first, though, is that Johan Huibers’ vessel has no motor, so he’ll need to rent tugboats to sail it.However, tugboats don’t come cheap and will cost the Dutch businessman, who made a fortune constructing storage spaces, more than £million to hire for the journey.Several years ago he was quoted saying he hoped to sail the -foot-wide vessel, which spans five floors and can hold more than , passengers, to Brazil. But those plans fell through.Now, he wants to take the ship to Israel, declaring his love for the Jewish state in an interview with the Jewish ic Agency, adding that “this is a copy of God’s ship. It only makes sense to take it to God’s land.“I love the county, I love the people. They don’t obey, they do what they want, they drive like mad, shove while waiting in line and don’t listen to anyone. Just like me.”The dad developed a strong urge to build the art after reading a story about it to his children one night in .His we, who works as a cop, initially laughed at him and said that once he’d finished building one, “we can all go on vacation to the moon”.However, he persisted and completed his first Noah’s Ark replica  years later.But Huibers was disappointed as it was “only half the size of the one in the Bible. So I sold the smaller one and built a le-size one too.”He told JTA that for the second major project, he was joined by amateur carpenters who’d had no training, including a “butcher, a hairdresser and a teacher.“We’re not professional boatmakers - a lot of stuff here is crooked.”That might explain why officials in Krimpen aan de Ijssel won’t let it reopen to visitors at present, because of public safety concerns.Yet Huibers told JTA that the ship is safe, insured and equipped with fire extinguishing gear.The boatmaker also said that he believes we are “living in the end of times” but that people aren’t “conscious” of it.“The water is going to come. From the mountains, from the sea, through Germany. It sounds like doom and gloom, but I’m not afraid of it,” he added.

title: mum spots giant spider lurking at the bottom of her half eaten lidl salad box but is all as it seems
story: Melissa Ryan-Skelly was disgusted after her daughter showed her what she had discovered hiding in the leafy greens at the bottom of her pre-made box.Melissa, a mother-of-four, posted the image to Facebook and tagged Lidl saying: “Look at what my daughter found in her salad!”The spider, which some said may be a False Widow, was covered in white salad dressing and was stuck to the bottom of the container when discovered.Plenty of Facebook-users shared their disgust over the massive creepy-crawly.Others compared it to a bushtucker trial on I’m A Celebrity….Get Me Out Of Here!Louise Heffernan said: “Jesus that’s a bush tucker trial.”Bridget Slattery said: “Oh my God, that’s disgusting, won’t be eating salad from there anymore.”Catherine Bermingham said: “I’m a spider get me out of here!”While some people were horried at the massive bug, some others didn’t believe Melissas story.Aine McCarthy said: “Can’t be real... he was he’d be dead andhe was dead he’d be curled up!”Melissa, of Kildare, Ireland, was quick to point out that the spider was indeed real and posted a picture of it flipped over on its front.She said: “No it’s real. Her dad pulled its legs out with the plastic fork to see how big it was when he realised what it was.”Lawrence Bee, of the British Arachnological Society, said the spider was almost certainly not British and had probably been imported with the salad.He added: “It happens all the time with supermarkets. Without seeing a clearer image it’s impossible to say what type of spider it is.”A Lidl spokesperson told The Sun Online: Our Customer Service team have been in contact with the customer and have explained that a full review of the incident is underway with our supplier.The purpose of the investigation is to ascertain the root cause of this incident and to promptly react by implementing corrective actions and preventative measuresnecessary.Please be assured that the complaint has been escalated to Management and we are treating it with utmost attention. We would like to apologise to both customers for the inconvenience this may have caused.

title: jungle gentleman harry redknapp jane moore opinion
story: “I do love her too much andanything happened it would just kill me,” says the former football manager.“We just get on so well. I only want to be with her. I can never wait to see her.”Cue the nation emitting a collective swoon and ’Arry becoming odds-on favourite to take the jungle crown.“Aw, he’s sooooo lovely,” gushed one twentysomething TV commentator, asHarry had just bequeathed all his worldly possessions to help save an endangered species.Given the borderline hysterical response to this “man still loves we after  years” declaration, he might even be considered one himself.But is it really so unusual  To those dating in this Tinder-centric age where people start swiping right the second there’s a minor hiccup, perhaps. But to my generation, less so.Shortly after my Uncle Jack died in his early eighties, my Aunty Mabel announced that she wouldn’t be around for much longer because she couldn’t bear to be without him. Sure enough, she literally lost the will to live and died soon after.It was the same story with my godparents and, as a trainee reporter, I interviewed countless golden wedding coupleswho had endured all manner of marital bumps in the road but lasted the course.How many of today’s liaisons will reach that -year milestone When Harry and Sandra took their vows, they clearly both understood the now largely outdated concept that love is a decision, not just a feeling.In other words, there might have been plenty of niggles and quarrels along the waybut they pushed on through in the knowledge that reaching old age with your spouse and best friend by your side is one of le’s greatest pleasures.The shared experiences, the joy of shared memories, the private jokes, the non-awkward silences and the companionship — bliss.Interestingly, Harry and Sandra’s marital set-up is one that’s increasingly regarded as outdated in this supposedly “progressive” day and age — that of the man bringing home the bacon while the woman runs the house and does the lion’s share of parenting.Consequently, Harry, now , freely admits he can barely make a cup of tea because Sandra does everything for him.It wouldn’t be my, er, cup of tea, but it has worked for them and perhaps it’s because Harry clearly doesn’t view Sandra as “just a housewe”he sees her as the boss and someone whose input he values and respects.And therein lies the key to a happy marriage. It doesn’t matter what the dynamic is as long as each feels appreciated and respected in their chosen role.Harry is what many might consider to be an old-fashioned gentleman, when men were allowed to be one without fear of being branded patronising.He turned away from the female contestants while they were showering and, whenever he gets the chance, awards “the ladies” the rare camp comforts on offer instead of the men.A magnanimous gesture, I notice, that they all accept readily without a passing thought that it might be unfair to the male contestants in these times of supposed equality for both genders.Ashley Roberts danced her bobby socks off in the Lindy hop on Saturday’s Strictly and performed a crackingly good samba too.But she ended up in the bottom two.Why  Because the public never like what they think might be a foregone conclusion.And however much the show tries to dress her up as a plucky amateur, her previous dance experience makes it as implausible as putting Bear Grylls in the I’m A Celebrity “jungle” and seeing him scream at the sight of a cockroach.Remember that moment in Crocodile Dundee when a yob pulls a blade on Mick Dundee in New York and he responds by saying “That’s not a kne”– “that’s a kne”.Fast forward  years and consider the story of Alun Powell, of Newport, Gwent, who takes part in medieval role-playing contests as “Sir Fightalot”.A court heard that when he arrived home to find his father being plagued by a gang outside the house, he pulled a sword, axe and knuckleduster from the boot of his car and “took up a fighting stance”.The prosecution added: “They saw the weapons and got so frightened that they left as quickly as possible.”Job done. End of. Right Nope. Alun ended up in court, convicted of possessing bladed articles in public and given  hours of community service.Perhaps this is why more members of the public don’t get involved when they see trouble.Becausethey don’t have a weapon themselves, they could get hurt.Andthey do happen to have one in their house or car, and brandish it in self-defence, there’s every chance they’ll end up in court themselves while the troublemakers get away scot-free.Robert de Niro is the new face of Warburtons bread.It’s hard to choose my favourite movies starring this acting titan, but Midnight Bun would be top, followed by The Kingsmill Of Comedy and Jackie Brown Bread.Posh store Anthropologie has been ridiculed for selling a bunch of twigs for £.But is the laugh on them or the idiots who buy them In the words of the marvellous Harry Enfield, it must include “we saw you coming” tax.Following on from the debate on whether or not they should have built a ramp to rescue stranded penguins, the crew of BBC’s wildle series Dynasties are in the news again for helping a stricken lion cub.As a rule, those who film such programmes are discouraged from intervening in the events they are trying to capture on the basis that nature should be allowed to take its course.But the cub was shown collapsing and spasming after eating bait laced with poison by tribesmen who had lost their cattle to a lion a few days earlier.So perhaps the new “rule” could be that human intervention is allowed when it’s human intervention that caused the crisis in the first place So how come a -year-old Iranian man – pretending to be  – was blithely placed in a class full of GCSE pupils in Ipswich without so much as a routine dental check Education Secretary Damian Hinds has added to the curriculum certain feats he wants primary school children to achieve before they move up to secondary.He says pupils will be urged to climb trees, explore caves and watch the sun rise to help build character.A good idea, but how depressing that all the things most of us did as a matter of routine in our youth now have to be actively prescribed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: armed forces employment chances research
story: The new study found veteran employment rates are at  per cent – above the national average of . per cent.And it found that  per cent of veterans who said they had a mental health disability were in work compared to just  per cent of civilians battling mental health woes being are in work.The report, conducted by the Veterans Work Consortium titled ‘Veterans Work: Moving On’, surveyed , UK veterans who had left the military in the past  years.Experts who commissioned the report said the figures undermined public perceptions that service le hampers veteran’s chances of getting work when they leave.Chris Recchia, Partner at Deloitte and Chair of the Veterans Work Consortium said: “This data dispels those negative stereotypes.“Our study found veterans are highly employable due to the hard work, determination, flexibility where they work and critically, a willingness to try a whole new career.“Persistent negative stereotypes do unfortunately affect wider societal perception of the veteran community.“It is absolutely true that some veterans have suffered and continue to suffer, this does not reflect the experiences of the majority.”Veterans Work, made-up of leading professional services firm Deloitte, the Armed Forces charity the Officers’ Association and The Forces in Mind Trust , is a consortium of organisations whose collective aim is to improve the understanding of veteran employment.Their study comes after a separate poll earlier this year found an alarming  per cent of civilians think veterans are more likely to suffer from more mental, physical and emotional issues than those who have never served.The YouGov report also found that  per cent of employers believe veterans are more likely to be “institutionalised”.And  per cent thought that serving in the Armed Forces “damages people”.Lee Holloway, Chief Executive of the Officers’ Association said: “There is a clear gulf between how the public perceive veterans and the reality.“Veterans are more likely to be employed for instance, regardless of disability or mental health.Air Vice-Marshal Ray Lock CBE and Chief Executive of the Forces in Mind Trust, said: “The transition out of military service into civilian le is most successful when all the elements, such as housing and employment, are tackled early, and holistically.“It’s important that these challenges are, though, represented in a balanced and proportionate way.Understanding the needs of the minority who do struggle should be set alongside the successful outcomes for the majority.“There is plenty of evidence to show that the public and employers hold inaccurate perceptions of the ex-Service community.“The efforts of the Veterans Work consortium should help redress the balance.”Tobias Ellwood, Minister for Defence People and Veterans, said: “Those who have served in our armed forces leave with a fantastic range of transferrable skills, including leadership, team work and resourcefulness.“Organisations can benefit signicantly from their experience, and so it’s important we dispel the myth that veterans are somehow damaged by their service.“We will continue to support our service leavers in whichever route they choose to take, through initiatives such as our Career Transition Partnership.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: poorly pooch high chair
story: The -month-old labrador has rare condition megaoesophagus, which leaves him unable to keep food down unless he is upright.He was half his ideal weight when Emma Drinkall, from Nottingham University’s veterinary school, read about his plight on social media.She and her partner Nick Rowan, a lecturer in product design and engineering at De Montfort University, came up with the chair in a day.Emma said: “Luckily Nick and I have the combined expertise and experience.“There is currently no surgery available for dogs with this condition, and as Buck is already receiving the medications that can help, the one thing other thing that could help him keep his food down is gravity itself.Nick added: “I’m just so pleased with how it fits, how comfortably he sits in it and how happy he is to be fed like this.Buck weighed just .lbs when he was taken in by the charity Team Edward Labrador Rescue, based in Mansfield, Notts.Wendy Hopewell, who runs Team Edward, said: “We were really shocked.“The previous owner said they were really struggling to feed him but when I saw him I thought ‘wow, I’ve never seen a labrador that thin before.“It was just the most fabulous sight to see Buck eating in the chair and happy to be in it.“To see how he sat in it straight away and get stuck in was incredible, it just pulls at your heartstrings.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lion air jet not airworthy
story: About three minutes after the Boeing  took off for its journey to Pangkal Pinang, the plane made erratic altitude changes.Ten minutes later, the plane crashed into waters off the Java coast killing all  people on board.Last night Nurcahyo Utomo, head of Indonesias national transport safety committee said: This is the basis of our recommendation to Lion Air. In our view, the plane was not airworthy.Preliminary data transmitted by flight  now suggests the troubled plane dropped at incredible speed — falling from an altitude of m in just  seconds.A normal descent for an airliner would be about m to m per minute, aviation safety expert John Cox told Bloomberg.Data obtained by FlightRadar shows the Lion Air flight JT- descending at more than m per minute.“This thing really comes unglued,” said Mr Cox, who runs consulting company Safety Operating Systems.“The numbers are barely believable.”An analysis of data from the crashed plane by the Aviation Safety website described its speed and altitude during its  minutes of flying as “erratic”.The plane made a climbing left-hand turn after take-off, climbed to m and then dropped down to m.It then climbed again and continued unsteadily for a few minutes between m and m before the fatal plunge.The Boeing  Max involved in yesterday’s crash had flown a dferent route on Sunday.Similar data shows it had erratic movements immediately after takeoff, but managed to climb and maintain a steady altitude.Lion Air has confirmed the aircraft had a “technical problem” on the Sunday flight, “which had been resolved according to the procedure”.What caused the strange changes in altitude and speed, and why the pilot asked toto Jakarta moments after takeoff, will now be a major focus for investigators.According to aviation consultant and former pilot Alastair Rosenschein, we won’t have a definitive answer on what caused the crash until authorities recover the plane’s black box.“It is almost impossible to say just what happened,” Mr Rosenschein told CNN. “At this point, some sort of mechanical failure is probably the most likely, but this is purely speculative.”The aviation expert said that until the black box is found, it would remain unlikely authorities could figure out what brought down the plane.He noted it’s especially important to find the black box quickly because the doomed plane was a newer model.“What happened here could possibly affect the same model of aircraft flying in other parts of the world,” he said.Investigators have deployed underwater beacons to trace the flight’s black box recorders, but so far they are yet to make a discovery.The top priority will be finding the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder to help determine the cause, safety experts said.

title: post brexit immigration plans delays eu workers
story: Home Secretary Sajid Javid was forced to admit details of a post-Brexit visa scheme may not come out until after MPs are asked to vote on the PM’s Brexit deal on December .He said he could only “hope” an Immigration White Paper would be ready - but that a draft was being held up by other Government departments.The Sun can reveal the delay stems from a bitter Cabinet war over the PM’s bid to halt as much low-skilled immigration as possible.One Cabinet Minister said the PM was in a “minority of one” as colleagues demand concessions so businesses can continue to recruit low-skilled EU workers.Sources claim both Chancellor Philip Hammond and Business Secretary Greg Clark are blocking a bid to rush out the paper because they want to soften the proposals.The PM’s close aides want the paper out before the Meaningful Vote on December  in a bid to show Brexit-backing MPs the UK is “taking back control” and ending free movement.But the Cabinet Minister told The Sun: “The PM is again completely isolated on this.The Ministers from the big economic departments won’t stand for it as they know how much the nation depends on lower skilled migrants.“Limiting immigration too much will do title: theresa may commons 200 vote defeat brexit deal
story: With just  days to go until the crucial “meaningful vote”, Cabinet ministers are considering urging her to abandon it.One has even said there is “zero chance” the deal will get through. But No  has warned that the PM will not ditch the deal — and will keep pushing it through Parliament until it passes.One Cabinet minister branded No’s refusal to change course in the face of overwhelming odds as “extraordinary”, adding: “There is zero chance the deal will pass now”.And a former minister – who is remaining loyal to Mrs May - has calculated that the Government will lose by a devastating  votes.The senior Tory warned of “a bandwagon effect” that is pushing an ever larger coalition of Brexiteer and Remainer MPs to side against Mrs May for a myriad dferent reasons, dubbing it “madness”.Another Cabinet minister told The Sun: “Theresa is still being told she can win this by the people around her in No.“It’s terrible advice and she deserves better, because they are going to bring her down.”By Tuesday night, a total of  Tory MPs had publicly declared their opposition to the deal - struck in Brussels on Sunday after  months of torturous negotiation - with more known to also oppose it.Mrs May was dealt a fresh hammer blow when loyal former Cabinet minister Sir Michael Fallon branded it “doomed”.Given that her deal is most likely dead, our politicians must start properly planning for a clean break from the EU to ensure minimal disruption.Evidently, the bloc is unwilling to compromise.Spain have already threatened us over Gibraltar and the French with fishing.The Government should prepare to call a national emergency to ensure we are ready in four months,necessary, to leave on our own terms.It is not good enough for the PM to plough on with her bad deal, blindly believing that she will get it through Parliament. The odds are stacked against her.The Government must pull its finger out and prepare for a No Deal scenario.The ex-Defence Secretary - forced to resign a year ago for sexual inappropriateness - stunned No by dubbing the agreement “the worst of all worlds”.Sir Michael also became the first senior Tory to call for a delay to Brexit on March  next year so negotiations for a better deal can be extended.Ministers have begun privately working on options for a Plan B within their own factions, but there is no agreement among them on what it should be yet.Tory whips are instead warning backbench MPs that the PM will refuse to abandon her deal evenMPs do vote it down on December .No will instead plan to put it to Parliament a second and even a THIRD time until it passes.One MP said: “They’re trying to bring it back at least twice - possibly a third time – after renegotiations.“I think she needs to be gone after the first time it falls, but they’re trying to keep her in position.”On another tense day in British politics:Mrs May began her frantic nationwide tour of the UK on Tuesday with visits to Wales and Northern Ireland to try to sell her Brexit deal to the country ahead of the showdown vote.She will also go to Scotland on Wednesday to insist the agreement delivers for fishermen by taking back control of the UK’s waters.But ahead of the PM’s arrival in Belfast, DUP chief Ms Foster said her visit would be “a waste of time” as she won’t reopen the agreement for an Irish backstop that sees dferent regulations for Ulster and the rest of the UK.Hitting back, Mrs May insisted the deal “protects” the UK, adding: “A very clear message that we have got here in Northern Ireland but where as well is that people do not want toto uncertainty and ision”.Cabinet ministers remained loyal in public today.Health Secretary Matt Hancock insisted MPs “should vote for the deal” saying it wasn’t “just the Government’s position - it’s the right thing to do”.Askedhe could guarantee that no-one would diethere was a no-deal Brexit, Mr Hancock told the Commons Health Committee: “As my permanent secretary tells me, we shouldn’t use words like guarantee.“What we can say is that we are confident thateverybody does what they need to do then there will be the continuity of supply.”Brexiteers last night warned that the Treasury’s analysis of the deal should be discarded as “yet more Project Fear”.The Sun can reveal that four dferent scenarios will be modelled against a baseline of staying in the EU, and all four are expected to show growth will be lost because of the decision to leave.They are the PM’s Chequers plan to align regulations on goods with the EU, membership of the EEA, a looser Canada-style free trade deal and no deal at all.Leading Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker said: “The reputation of government economics is in the gutter. That must change.“It’s time for the Chancellor to publish all his assumptions and full model documentation so we can begin the process of recovery.”Meanwhile Home Secretary Sajid Javid on Tuesday night admitted there was “no guarantee” the UK would be given access to two critical EU-wide crime databases.He admitted the Political Declaration only laid out plans to cooperate on finding “approximate measures” to cooperate on crime fighting.Currently police chiefs can access the Schengen Information Systemand ECRIS, the European Criminal Records Information System to check suspects against a list of third country nationals.Police accesses SISII more than  million times last year.Mr Javid told MPs: “Within this document [the Political Declaration] it’s within scope but it’s not guaranteed.”The Home Secretary insisted “almost of all my counterparts” in the EU want to cooperate on security in “much the same way”.But Labour’s Stephen Doughty revealed the PM’s chief of staff admitted  to opposition MPs at a private briefing on Monday night it would be “very dficult” to maintain access to SISII.Mr Doughty said: “Gavin Barwell told us it’s going to be an even bigger challenge to stay connected to SISII than it was to join it in the first place.”Ministers are also on course for a fresh showdown with the House of Commons when it emerged Downing Street will not publish the full Brexit legal advice – giving MPs “full, reasoned position statement” instead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may government accused veil secrecy ndas no deal brexit
story: New figures revealed the Department for Transport alone has  non-disclosure agreements in force - forbidding companies and organisations from discussing plans about borders and customs.The Department for Exiting the European Unionhas six – and insists they are “entirely normal practice”.Just two months ago Theresa May branded the use of NDAs by employers to gag staff as “unethical”.But haulage firms and drug companies are thought to be among those who now face an injunctionthey break the terms of the ious gagging orders.Lib Dem MP and Best for Britain campaigner Layla Moran stormed: “The Government is throwing a veil of secrecy over critical plans.“There is a massive element of hypocrisy that the Prime Minister would say she opposes non-disclosure agreements but yet her departments use them. It is shameless.”The revelations in a string of written Parliamentary answers came as a scathing cross-party report warned of chaos at ports and motorways in a No Deal.MPs on the Public Accounts Committee slammed inadequate planning and “complacency” at the Department of Transport.They said there was a “real risk” of chaos at Dover and found “slow progress and poor communication” around work to avoid disruption through schemes such as Project Brock, where overflow traffic parked on the M in Kent.Separately, representatives of the food and drinks industry warned it was already too late for companies to book extra space to stockpile extra supplies in the run-up to Brexit in March because of over-demand.Ian Wright, boss of the Food and Drink Federation, said warehouses for frozen and chilled food were “for all practical purposes booked out at the moment”.A Government spokesperson said it was wrong to suggest NDAs were “designed to prevent organisations from raising any concerns”.He said: “They are in place simply to protect commercial and sensitive issues, which is consistent across government.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal worst both worlds
story: He talks in sweeping generalisations and is often criticised for inaccuracies, even outright hoods.How then should we react to the leader of the free world claiming the UK’s withdrawal agreement with the EU could mean that we would be “unable to trade” with the US This is a classic example of the need to take Donald Trump seriously, but not literally.There are no imaginable circumstances in which Britain will be blocked from trading with America.We can do so at present, even as full members of the EU.If we couldn’t, I must have imagined visiting the States and buying their products.Trade happens and will continue to do so, whatever arrangements the UK finally finds itself in.But President Trump’s intervention speaks to a deeper, more subtle truth.If the UK effectively remains in an EU customs union and without control over our regulatory system then it’s dficult to see how trade with the US will accelerate and flourish.The same goes with the rest of the non-EU world.The dficulty with Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement is that it substantially limits the capacity for the UK to strike its own trade deals.Indeed, it would make such deals almost impossible.Downing Street has hit back at this by pointing to wording in the agreement that states the UK will be entitled to reach arrangements with other countries.But this amounts to little more than a theoretical possibility given it is not made clear when,ever, we will finally be out of this “customs territory”.To grasp this problem, it is important to understand how trade negotiations work.Let’s say you and I sit round a table and go through all the things hindering trade between our two nations.Perhaps I am applying high tarfs on your wine and you are applying exorbitant tarfs on my cars.We negotiate, so more of my countrymen can drink your wine, and more of your citizens can drive my cars.To reach such accords, you need to be in full control of your own customs arrangements.If my starting point is that I can’t reduce the tarf on your wine because I’m locked into an agreement with the EU that fixes the tarf, my negotiations with you are unlikely to get off the ground.American wine, for instance, is subject to a tarf of either .p or p per ­bottle, depending on strength.A bottle of Jack Daniel’s is hit by a  per cent import tarf to the EU, while American cars are subject to a ten per cent import tarf.Meanwhile, the EU recently announced a plan to hit American motorcycles, such as Harley-Davidsons with a  per cent tarf — hugely pushing up the price.A larger part of the negotiation tends to focus on regulatory barriers to trade.Although tarfs on products mean higher prices in the shops, they do not necessarily prevent foreign prod­­ucts getting to the market.But dferences in regulation can have just this effect.If, to oversimply, all of your nails need, by law, to be in long and all of the nails in my country need to be in long, we won’t see much trade in nails between us — evenno tarfs are imposed.To improve our trading relations we need to look at whether we can agree to align some of our regulations, repeal some or respect each other’s regulatory standards.If we do not control our rules and cannot alter or abolish them, negotiations are pretty pointless.And not just with the US, but with other major economies, such as Australia and Japan.The UK faces a classic trade- off here.If what you prioritise above all  is to minimise any friction in trade between the UK and the EU, you will want to stay highly aligned with the EU’s regulations — and you may well conclude that it is easier to simply stay in the EU itself.In that case, you will also probably want the UK to join the euro, because having a dferent currency to France and Germany adds costs to our trade with them.Butyou are looking to the rest of the world, you may feel we should be able to strike a simple but comprehensive free trade deal with the EU.Trade across the Channel might not be as seamless as at present, but we would be free to strike deals to improve trade across the Atlantic and the Pacic.If Mrs May’s is the deal we are left with, those hoping for a global Britain post-Brexit will be deeply disappointed.Even a no-deal scenario would at least unshackle the UK from EU rules and provide more autonomy over our future trading relationships with the rest of the world.Trade with the EU is important to the UK, but it is declining.Over the next decade,  per cent of all global economic growth is predicted to come from outside the European Union.If you see Brexit as a historic opportunity to make Britain a global trading nation, you will have a lot of sympathy with President Trump’s sentiments.This might explain why so many see Mrs May’s proposals as the worst of both worlds.They surrender our seat at the EU table, without giving us the freedom to properly reach out across the seas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paloma faith new mum is difficult
story: “Motherhood was much more dficult than I anticipated because I hadn’t heard the truth and I think not enough people speak about it,” Paloma said. “Obviously everyone’s experience is dferent and I have met mums who sailed through it but I didn’t. I was really shell-shocked.”It seems like such a simple admission. But the reality is that with most celebrities, from the Kardashians to the Beckhams, projecting an unfeasibly perfect image of parenthood as part of their brand, many expectant mums think a new baby is going to be a walk in the park.The reality for most of us really couldn’t be further from the truth.Paloma also talked about the dficulty of balancing being a new mother with having a career.“I found it very dficult, the pull between wanting to be the greatest mother ever but also trying to sustain an inherently selfish career,” she said.The transition from being a woman with a career and all the time in the world to a mother wanting to continue working is no easy feat.There’s a period of adjustment and, often, the road is rocky. So here’s the reality, for what it’s worth.In my experience, EVERY woman who is a parent finds motherhood hard at some point or ­another, but especially at the beginning. And the women who seem to be sailing through it are often putting on a brave face, partly because they feel under pressure to do so.Often, people’s public portrayal of their le, including motherhood, is heavily edited, airbrushed and ­censored.The pressure on women for everything, including motherhood, to be “perfect” is clear.And,that isn’t your experience, with everyone  seemingly acing it, the pressure is on to pretend that it is.The vicious cycle is born. So it’s brave of Paloma to talk about her experience out loud.Given that every mum in the history of the universe has felt this way about motherhood at one time or another, we should be more honest about admitting it to be true.Modern pressures are making it so dficult I have to say I’m so glad I’m not raising a child today.The internet had still not been invented. The Twitter and Instagram inventors had probably not even been born.When I was growing up the only “influencers” in my le were my mum and dad.We ate as a family every night and there were three channels on the TV that all stopped airing by midnight. You had to make your own entertainment.Nowadays you can’t move for influencers on YouTube, Instagram and Twitter telling your kids how they should look or feel — and ­promoting lestyles that are simply unattainable.No wonder there has been such a dramatic rise in young people self-harming and taking anti- depressants. Too many influencers, who are hashtag “blessed”, don’t talk about the dficult stuff.Paloma, by the way, is raising her child as “gender neutral” — a ­decision that seems to be another indication of the pressures that ­people are under to do the right thing by their children.Too much choice and too much pressure to do the right thing and be the perfect parent can lead to paranoia.The best advice I could give a parent now that my own two are  and  is to find your own path.Don’t look too hard at what everyone  is doing.Don’t compare yourself to any other mothers, especially not celebrities with a team of personal trainers and chefs, and who snap back into shape two weeks after giving birth.Instead of aiming for perfect, just try to do your best.Listen, understand and give your child the one thing that really does matter: Self-esteem.Talk to other women, and be honest, evenyou are finding it hard. Because it IS bloody hard.So good for Paloma for being honest and fighting the tide of propaganda about motherhood.Because being honest makes it easier for other women who might be struggling.ISN’T it incredible to think that a hundred years ago, on November , , women were allowed to stand for parliament in the UK for the very first time Fast forward to the  General Election when  female MPs were elected.Yes, that’s in relation to  male MPs, so we still have a way to go – but look how far we have come.I know I am biased, but women are such a brilliant parliamentary asset.Look at all the things they bring to the table and to the conversation.Women are great listeners, good mediators, brilliant diplomats and inspiring promoters of family and equal rights. Oh, and we are resilient.Just look at Theresa May who, at a time when most men would be hiding under the duvet and emitting a high-pitched wailing noise, is rising to the unbelievable challenges being thrown at her by the Brexit process – and enjoying beans on toast with her husband Philip in the evening.Compare her to a politician such as Jacob Rees-Mogg who is doing everything he possibly can to promote himself and his political ambitions – rather than focusing on what the country needs.The PM is the living embodiment of resilience – a tough old bird indeed.ANYONE in a long-term marriage should take note of Dolly Parton’s insights on what makes her -year union work.“When people ask me what’s the key to my long marriage and lasting love, I always say, ‘Stay gone’,” the singer, reveals. “I travel a lot, but we really enjoy each other when we’re together and the little things we do.”Her husband Carl doesn’t like to appear in public or walk the red carpet – so she leaves him at home.Instead of glamorous date nights, they take trips in a “little camper”, go on picnics and eat at local restaurants, including a drive-thru McDonald’s.But eventhey are having a quiet night in, she says she always makes sure she is “fixed up for him because I don’t believe in going home and being a slouch”.You’ve got to love Dolly.NOT many people can ooze class, charm and elegance with their leg raised higher than their head – at the age of .Butthere’s one woman who can, it’s the glorious Darcey Bussell, who must be one of the nicest, and classiest, women in showbiz today.Goldman was one of the first corporate firms to introduce “lactation rooms” for women to express milk and it also runs free prenatal fitness classes at its office gym.It also has on-site day care where employees’ children are cared for  days per year for free.All of which is great – and let’s hope more companies follow suit for new parents.Mind you, it’s not like the need for childcare ever really stops – I still need an emergency nanny occasionally when my -year-old daughter loses her keys or my -year-old son locks himself out.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mo farah golliwog christmas market
story: The sportsman was depicted as a racist caricature striking his classic Mo-bot pose in a white vest with his surname on it at a stall in Rochester.The term golly doll stems from a fictional character depicted as a rag doll in the children’s story The Adventures Of Two Dutch Dolls And A Golliwogg created by writer Florence Kate Upton in the th Century.The name became associated with racist connotations when it was used as a derogatory term for black people in World War Two.A photo also shows a Bob Marley doll on sale for £. at Rochester Christmas Market.Following complaints over the golly dolls at the council-run event, officials blasted the caricature of the national hero, adding selling the dolls was completely inappropriate.Councillor and leader of Medway Labour Group Vince Maple said: Mo Farah is a national hero and an internationally respected athlete so to have somebody selling dolls of this nature is completely inappropriate at a council-run Christmas event.Its supposed to a Dickensian event and these dolls are neither Christmassy nor Dickensian.Cllr Maple previously tweeted that he had received an email about a stall selling the racist dolls.He said he had written urgently to Medway Council officers to seek action on the matter.Cllr Howard Doe, cabinet member for community services, said: We do not allow Gollys to be sold at the Rochester Christmas Market.We permitted the sale of Rasta dolls within the City of Rochester Craft Fair, at the Rochester Christmas Market last year.However, following reports that similar dolls were being sold at the market last weekend we have reviewed the situation again.Although the dolls are not labelled as Gollys we understand that they may unintentionally cause offence to some visitors.We have therefore decided to ask the stallholder to withdraw the dolls from sale.The banning of the dolls at the market comes just months after a man was fined £ for displaying a golliwog with noose around its neck in his flat window in North Wales.Jason Wakefield-Jones, , was reported to police after two residents spotted the doll peering out of the first-floor of his flat with a noose around its neck.The property in Prestatyn, North Wales, was across the road from two Indian restaurants and Wakefield-Jones admitted displaying it with intent to cause harassment, alarm or distress and that the offence was title: family hoard food no deal brexit
story: Nevine Mann, , and her husband Richard, , said they have been buying extra food and medicine each time they go shopping ahead of the March  Brexit deadline.The couple, who live in Illogan, near Redruth, with their three children Oliver, , Ethan,  and Paige, five, have also stockpiled tinned goods, dried milk, coffee and pasta.Nevine insists stockpiling is a matter of survivalTheresa Mays Brexit deal doesnt make it past the parliament vote on December .Since Brexit negotiations began, Nevine said they started buying more dried food and believe they have enough goods to survive a No Deal Brexit for at least four months.She said: The results of a No Deal Brexit would be catastrophic in terms of getting supplies in the country, certainly in the short term. Were waiting to seethe new deal goes through or not.She continued: If that doesnt go through, it will be No Deal because there wont be enough time to sort another one out.We started buying extra of things we would usually buy. When we are shopping we buy beans for now and beans for later, rice for now and rice for later. There are a few things we wouldnt usually buy, like sources of vegetarian protein and powdered milk.Nevine, who home schools the couples children, added: Weve got baked beans, chickpeas, couscous, pasta - weve got things like tea, coffee, Ovaltine... We also bought Marmite so we can have some flavour.While the stockpiling measures may seem extreme to some, Nevine insists the family are not going over the top, adding: Weve got enough to get us through the first couple of monthsthere is No Deal.The Mann familys cupboards are already stocked with  tins of beans,  cans of tuna, large tubs of mayonnaise, eight cans of chopped tomatoes and four packets of passata.Nevine added: Its not about being able to live comfortably, its about being able to survive.The familys stockpiling comes after industry leaders revealed food warehouses are now fully stocked for the next six months after an unprecedented rush in the days following the publication of Theresa May’s draft Brexit deal.The Food Storage and Distribution Federation warned that Britain isn’t set up for stockpiling food but storage space is now fully reserved from January to April - usually the quietest time of the year.FSDF boss Shane Brennan told the : “It’s a problem, because food is manufactured or stored on a just-in-time basis, and the system isn’t built for stockpiling.“But because of Brexit, every business that wants to guarantee its supply into UK shelves is looking for additional warehouse space right now.”On December , MPs will vote on the withdrawal agreement that was approved by EU leaders on November , .Parliament has demanded that the Brexit treaty can only be ratied by the Government after it has been “approved by a resolution of the House of Commons on a motion moved by a minister of the crown”.The vote will be a straight yes no format in a bid to make a decisive and unequivocal decision on the PMs deal.But the outlook for the vote isnt positive as Theresa May has already had two ministers resign over the deal and her own Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, also quit as the draft deal was presented to Parliament.Labour and factions within her own party have declared their intention to vote against it.

title: living wage boost thousands workers
story: NewsLiving Wage boost for thousands of workers in Heathrow Airport supply chainEXCLUSIVE: The west London travel hub announced the pay hike for an estimated , workersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV NewsHeathrow Airport announced the pay boost for workers in its supply chain "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritains biggest airport is banning zero-hours’ contracts and insisting suppliers pay workers the “real”LivingWage, we can reveal. In a major victory for campaigners, Heathrow Airport ruled all contractors must sign up to paying their staff at least the voluntary rate which is higher than the Government’s legal minimum. The move is set to benefit an estimated , of low-paid workers who are vital for the hub to operate. Transport bosses also told would-be contractors staff cannot be placed on zero-hours’ deals and must instead be guaranteed a flow of work. The shake-up, which executives have dubbed a “roadmap”, will apply to all new contracts signed from December. Staff with suppliers who have existing deals with Heathrow – which already pays its , directly-employed workers at least theLivingWage- must wait until the end of  before all benefit. LivingWageFoundation director Tess Lanning said: “Heathrow’s commitment to pay a realLivingWagehas already had a huge impact on workers.  “Low pay can be tackled in our offices, shops, warehouses and airports, but we now need to see more employers follow Heathrow’s lead and commit to a fair day’s pay for a hard day’s work.” Campaigners want businesses to commit to paying the realLivingWagerather than the Government’s NationalLivingWage, which is a re-branded minimum legal floor. The minimum pay rate for workers aged  and over is pound. compared with theLivingWage, paid by employers accredited with theLivingWageFoundation, which is pound. an hour in London and pound outside the capital. Analysts calculate the voluntary rate taking into account costs like housing, travel and healthy food, and extras like kids’ birthday presents.  Bosses say it helps companies’ reputations, employee retention and boosts staff motivation. Heathrow said a realLivingWagewould produce “higher morale, productivity and lower turnover” among workers. Some % of “target contracts” already in operation will be amended by autumn  to take effect of its new rules, with all workers at contractors earning at least theLivingWageby the end of .  One directly-employed worker who benefits from the realLivingWage, Alison Neill of the airport’s business support centre in Glasgow said: “Before I earned theLivingWage, I was struggling to keep on top of escalating debt, which was affecting my health, and quality of le. “One year on from being lted onto theLivingWageand I’m now on top of my finances, much happier and more motivated in my role because I’m no longer worried about being overwhelmed with debt.”   Trades Union Congress regional secretary Sam Gurney said: “We welcome the commitment of major employers like Heathrow Airport to ensure that their people and those in their supply chains receive LondonLivingWageand have regular guaranteed hours. “Heathrow’s roadmap must help ensure that those workers who do not currently receive LondonLivingWagewill do so as soon as possible.”

story: NewsBritish girl, , found on Tunisian beach after wandering from hotels kids clubElla Byrson, who was on a Thomas Cook holiday with her parents, was said to be distressed and tearful when she was found by a fellow holidaymakerShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV NewsThomas Cook said they are investigating the incident "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA two-year-old British child was found wandering along a Tunisian beach after vanishing from a hotel kids club. Her parents Billy and Claire, said the organisers of the kids club had not realised she was missing, reports The Scotsman. Dad Billy, , from Angus, Scotland, said: Somebody could have grabbed her on the beach or she could have gone into the water and drowned. If somebody had picked her up, how were security going to know that she wasn’t just crying for her mum ” The family were on holiday at the Sahara Beach AquaPark Resort, near the city of Monastir.  Ellas parents, who booked their holiday through Thomas Cook, had dropped her off in the kids club run by the hotel as opposed to the travel firm. Mum Claire, , said her daughter was in such a state when she was ed to her - commenting on how she was red and shaking. Billy said he complained to a rep about what happened, only to be told the rep wasnt even aware of the incident. He added: When I went back to tell her that my daughter had been brought back to us, she wasn’t even aware that she was missing. She had no clue where my daughter was.  More then a month ing home from holiday, Ellas parents said she is still traumatised by her experience. Dad Billy said Ella, now three, grips onto his hand as tight as she can while theyre out in public, and climbs on him to be carried. He said before, she was never like that. Claire took to social media to criticise Thomas Cook, writing: What did Ella have to do  Be kidnapped or drown or something for them to take it seriously ” A Thomas Cook spokeswoman said: “Customer safety is our first priority, so we were very concerned to hear of this incident and we understand how distressing it must have been. “We are urgently investigating with the hotel to get to the bottom of what happened and make any changes needed.”

story: NewsCross-dressing teenager, , models look on Margaret Thatcher after becoming fan at While most -year-olds know little about the complex world of politics, Tom Hulme from Oldham, Manchester, had already joined the Tory partyShareCommentsByBecca HusselbeeAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video cross-dressing-teenage-boy-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cross-dressing -year-old models his look on former Tory Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher - after becoming a fan at the age of just . While most -year-olds know little about the complex world of politics, Tom Hulme from Oldham, Manchester, had already joined the Tory party after hearing about the referendum. Tom is such a firm supporter of the Conservatives, he even dresses like Thatcher, Prime Minister from  - . He described himself as the Iron Ladys biggest fan. Tom started dressing in womans clothes from the age of  and describes how it came naturally to him after he first tried on a dress in secret. He now spends hours applying make-up, choosing outfits and decorating his room with posters of the former PM as well as visiting people in his local constituency.  Tom, a student at the University of Lincoln, said: I have always been interested in what was going on in the world but my interest really started when I noticed the coalition was happening. Looking back, my friends were always intrigued by me and when I joined the party and started getting invites for events with the Prime Minister, they showed a lot more interest. They were always very accepting of me though. I found the party shared my views and beliefs and I wanted to be a part of that. In terms of dressing dferently, its something I had wanted to do for a long time and it just came naturally. I was dressing up in my room from the age of  and it just felt right, it was like a missing piece.  It became more public when I was around  and I just decided that everyone knew it was happening anyway, so why not  This was how I wanted to be seen. Tom, now in his second year of studying politics and sociology, comes from a humble, working-class background but says he was inspired by the former Prime Minsters upbringing, that in some ways was similar to his own. Although originally Tom never planned to look like his role model, Maggie, after comments from friends and party members comparing him to the previous leader of the Conservative party, he soon started to fashion a similar look. He said: Hearing about Maggies upbringing was so inspiring for me and the story of how she came to be. It made me believe thatshe could do it then even I can make it in the world of politics. She managed to push and shout through a world of men, its an amazing story.  People started telling me that my look was similar to hers and I thought I would embrace that. She had a great sense of style. Tom was able to attend the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham this year, meeting MP Penny Mordaunt, the Minister for Women and Equalities, and MP Nicky Morgan but says he doesnt envy Theresa Mays position at the top. He said: The conference was so much fun and in a way a felt like the way I dressed almost gives me a sense of power, people treated me with more respect. Tom says that it was initially a shock to his parents after revealing his true identity to them but that they have now accepted him and his beliefs and are very proud of his achievements. He now has dreams of becoming a mental health nurse but says that becoming an MP would never be off the table. He said: My family are very supportive of me but it took them a while to get used to the idea.  I never wanted to push the way I am onto people, or force them to accept it. I do understand that politics is not a straightforward career butthe opportunity came up I would be happy to become an MP. I care passionately about this country and would always like to give something back.

story: NewsEdinburgh Zoo panda Yang Guang has testicles removed meaning no breeding for UK pairYang Guang, who is recovering from his surgery, arrived at Edinburgh Zoo in .ShareCommentsByLucinda CameronAbigail OLeary:,  NOV NewsYang Guang had developed testicular tumours "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEdinburgh Zoo panda Yang Guang - the only male giant panda in the UK - has had his testicles removed. Yang Guang, who is recovering from his surgery, arrived at Edinburgh Zoo in . He underwent the operation to remove both testicles following a group consultation involving British and Chinese giant panda specialists. The zoo said the tumours developed recently and have not been a factor in Yang Guang and female panda Tian Tiannot having had a cub. The operation took place on Saturday November , the Royal Zoological Society of Scotlandsaid. Edinburgh Zoo will now look into future breeding opportunities.  Darren McGarry, head of living collections at the zoo, said: We are pleased Yang Guang is recovering well. Testicular tumours have previously been reported in giant pandas. The tumours we removed developed recently so they have not been a factor in Yang Guang and Tian Tian not having had a cub. We will discuss next steps, including future breeding possibilities, with our partners in China over coming weeks.  The black and white bears arrived on loan from China in December  and are due to remain at Edinburgh Zoo for a decade. Tian Tian has had cubs in China but not in the UK. The zoo tried natural breeding in  and has attempted articial insemination each year since . Earlier this year, RZSS said no efforts to breed the pair would take place in .

title: family prepare no deal brexit
story: NewsFamily prepare for No Deal Brexit by stockpiling essential itemsNevine Mann, , and her husband Richard, , from Cornwall have enough goods to survive a no-deal Brexit for at least four monthsShareCommentsByJohn Bett:,  NOV NewsNevine Man with her daughter Paige aged five, at their home in Cornwall "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family are getting ready for Brexit by stocking up on essential items - such as tea bags, baked beans and Marmite. Married couple Nevine Mann, , and Richard, , have been buying extra food and medicine every time they go shopping so they are prepared for when Britain leaves the European Union. So far they have stockpiled chickpeas, kidney beans, tuna, pasta, rice, couscous, chopped tomatoes, sterilised milk, tinned corn, beans, paracetamol and ibuprofen. The family have also bought piles of aspirin, Calpol, dried milk, honey, Marmite, porridge oats, raisins, bread, flour, yeast and coffee. In addition, the clan also boats supplies of tea, sugar, apple juice, orange juice, Ovaltine and hand soap.  They believe they have now amassed enough goods on their kitchen table to survive a no-deal Brexit - for at least four months. Their cupboards are already stocked with  tins of beans,  cans of tuna, large tubs of mayonnaise, eight cans of chopped tomatoes and four packets of passata. There are also two large tubs of milk powder, several large bags of rice, pasta, tri colour quinoa and couscous. Since the Brexit negotiations began, Nevine said they started buying more dried food and fruit as it would last longer, as well as extra pet food.  The expanded shopping list also includes seeds so she can grow her own food in her garden, and equipment to pury rainwater. The Manns also have solar  on the roof and a -gallon water tank as they fear power could also be in short supply once Britain exits the EU. Nevine said she was also stockpiling her own medication, as she takes anti-epilepsy and blood-thinning drugs. And the couple, who live in Illogan, Cornwall, with her three children Oliver, , Ethan,  and Paige, five, insisted it wasnt about luxuries - but was a matter of survival.  Nevine, a former midwe, said: A little while ago we were aware that Brexit was in the offing, and it seemed like there would be issues with securing a deal. The results of a no deal Brexit would be catastrophic in terms of getting supplies in the country, certainly in the short term. We started buying extra of things we would usually buy. When we are shopping we buy beans for now and beans for later, rice for now and rice for later. Weve got about enough for four months.  The Manns have been doing their shopping at their local Sainsburys, Tesco and Aldi stores. Nevine, who homeschools the couples children, added: There are a few things we wouldnt usually buy, like sources of vegetarian protein and powdered milk. Weve got baked beans, chickpeas, couscous, pasta - weve got things like tea, coffee, Ovaltine, things like that. We also bought marmite so we can have some flavour.. Were basically there now so we will slow down now. Were not going over the top, weve got enough to get us through the first couple of monthsthere is no deal.  Were planting seeds in the garden and weve got extra to plant in spring. No deal Brexit is looking more and more likely, were waiting to seethe new deal goes through or not. If that doesnt go through it will be no deal because there wont be enough time to sort another one out. Its not about being able to live comfortably, its about being able to survive.

title: john kinsella paul massey trial
story: NewsJohn Kinsella and Paul Massey trial: Gunman executed mob fixer "like in a film"Wendy Owen was terried when she watched John Kinsella being shot dead in front of her by a cyclist who hid his face, a court heardShareByNeil Docking:,  NOV NewsJohn Kinsella was shot and killed like in a film, Liverpool Crown Court heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe girlfriend of an underworld figure watched in horror as a gunman executed him like in a film, a court heard. John Kinsella, , was shot four times by a masked cyclist while walking his dogs with Wendy Owen in St Helens. Prosecutors saya gangland feud lay behind his killing, and that of Salfords Mr Big Paul Massey, almost three years earlier. Liverpool Crown Court heard the two friends were caught up in a war between rival gangs, which pitted them against Mark Fellows and Steven Boyle - who are both accused of murdering the pair, reports the Liverpool Echo. The court heard Miss Owen was also shot at when an assassin struck on a country lane near the couples Rainhill home.   A video of her interview with police - just hours after the shooting at around .am on May  this year- was today played in court. They were walking six bulldogs along their usual route when Miss Owen said she heard the braking wheels of a mountain bike. She recalled hearing a puff noise, plus a shout or a raised voice, and initially thinking the cyclist wanted them to put their dogs on a lead. Miss Owen demonstrated how Kinsella staggered, assomething got him in the leg, and said she thought: Oh my God, he’s shooting at us. She said she screamed and approached the gunman, who turned to shoot at her. She said: I remember thinking he’s not stopping. Miss Owen said she ducked, then jumped over a fence to escape, shouted for help and flagged down a van on the M junction  slip road. Miss Owen said nothing was said by the shooter, or Kinsella, adding: I think he was in shock because he was getting attacked. She described looking back over the bushes and seeing the gunman move closer to Kinsella, then shoot him as he lay on the ground. Miss Owen said the weapon, which an officer told her may have been equipped with a silencer, sounded like a pellet gun.  The witness said the gunman was cool and only interested in her after she confronted him, before he ed to Kinsella. She said: He’s just gone forward again. As I’m replaying it in my mind, speaking about it, he’s wanted to keep, it’s like he wanted to finish the job. I know this sounds silly, but think of films, when they want to keep, it was like in a film when he wanted to finish the job and go. I thought bloody hell it’s like a film, he wants to finish what he’s doing. The jury heard a statement from a workman, who with a colleague found hysterical Miss Owen, then tried to help Kinsella. A police officer also spoke to her when she later ed to the scene in her Mercedes, after dropping off her bulldogs at home. He said: When questioned she said John was not in dispute with anyone or involved in drug supply. He bought and sold cars. [She said] he had been in prison about five years ago but was now behaving, as he didn’t want to go back there. She said he did have previous for armed robbery. The officer said he was later tasked with going to Miss Owens home to tell her Kinsella was dead. He said she came outside and said he’s dead, he’s dead isn’t he , to which he replied yes.  Miss Owen, who gave birth on Sunday, will be cross-examined later in the trial, via video link from a remote location. Firearms expert Andre Horn told the court Kinsella was shot twice from behind in the back, then twice in the back of the head. He said one round entered his lower back and exited through his chest, suggesting he was leaning forward, trying to dodge the bullet. Mr Horn said one went through his spine, so he would have collapsed, and three rounds were left lodged in his abdomen and head. He said the bullets indicated the assassin used a British-manufactured Webley revolver, which was last in service in the s. However, the expert said he did not find any of the bullets in the vast field which Miss Owens said were fired at her.

story: NewsMeghan Markles first year in Royal spotlight: How the Duchess is doing so farMeghan Markle and Prince Harry announced their engagement on November ,  to the delight of royal fans around the worldShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsMeghan stepped into the royal spotlight a year ago "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA year ago today, Meghan Markle joined Prince Harry in the gardens of Kensington Palace to pose for photos shortly after announcing their engagement to the world. And what a year its been. The couple had a stunning fairytale wedding with a host of A-list guests, attended a iety of events and engagements, embarked on a -day tour around New Zealand and Australia and theyre now expecting their first child. Meghans le changed forever the moment she showed off her huge diamond engagement ring her le, and her Royal journey officially began. The Duchess of Sussex appears to have gone from strength to strength as she learns the ropes, winning fans on both sides of the Palace gates.  The Duchess has had a lot to learn over the last  months, all while dealing with a lot of embarrassing family dramas. As well as standing proudly by Harrys side, shes also taken on her first solo project - a charity cook book to raise money for a community kitchen which supports people affected by the Grenfell Tower tragedy - and given a number of moving speeches at official events. Weve spoken to some of the people who have been following her every move ever since the engagement to see what they think of Britains new Duchess. Russell Myers - Royal Correspondent, Daily Mirror It goes without question that Meghan has got off to a cracking start but undoubtedly she is still settling into her role within the royal family.Many thought that her accomplished acting background would be a great advantage and at times it most probably has.When it comes to the meet and greets, the crowds and the speeches, she’s hit the ground running.A couple of bumps in the road early on might have thrown her off course. The not wearing a hat for her first engagement with the Queen and of course the awkwardness of not knowing what side of the car to get in behind the monarch. But slowly shes started to make her mark with caused that are clearly dear to her, with the Grenfell survivors’ cookbook and speaking up for women’s rights and education on her recent tour of Australasia and the Pacic Islands.Clearly the public adore her. She has brought a new energy to the royal family. Some undeniable Hollywood glamour even.But leaks of mild tantrums and complaints from staff about how she addresses them won’t sit wellshe doesn’t adjust.She’s entered a le of duty, the one thing the British public and indeed the world over admire most about the Queen.Kate Middleton mastered this early on and throughout her time as the Duchess of Cambridge has shown herself to be a class act.Whether she’s dressed in a designer dress at a royal ball, doing charity work or playing with children in the mud at an inner city school. Meghan, at least on the outside, has shown herself to be a quick learner and I’m sure we will see the best of her next year when she is expected to announce the causes that she will focus on moving forward.One thing is for certain, with a baby and a big house move on the way, it’s going to be a bumper year for the Sussexes.Ian Vogler - Photographer, Daily Mirror Having photographed the Royals over the years , since Harry and William where children, its been a really interesting year to see Harry grow into his new role as husband and future father. Since the couples engagement a year ago its been whirlwind of events including the rather dferent royal wedding at Windsor. Meghan has certainly added some Hollywood dazzle to the Royal family, without any doubt shes doing it her way.  One of the first engagements the undertook with Prince Harry was in Brixton SW London back in January. I was struck by the warmth of the crowd towards the Duchess, she was welcomed by one of the most erse crowds I have ever seen for a Royal event. Local people I met on the day said: “She’s one of us”. On that day she went with a classic MS top, perhaps the start of her becoming a Brit  On the recent trip to Australia and New Zealand Meghan spent a lot of time engaging with young people on the subject of Mental Health. This is a cause close to Prince Harrys heart, and the couple have really worked hard in this arena. They always stay longer at events than the palace officials anticipate.  Meghan seems to have taken on the role of Duchess without the need for any rehearsals, she is very comfortable in front of the camera and a great public speaker. Her recent speech at the Invictus Games in Sydney showed that. Looking back on the year so far that Meghan has been part of the Royal Family I would say shes really moulded herself into the role of a Modern Duchess. story: NewsSick puppy has to eat his dinner in a HIGH CHAIR so he doesnt starve to deathBuck the -month-old Labrador suffers from a rare condition called megaesophagus which means he could diehe doesnt eat sitting upShareCommentsByHayley Coyle:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video sick-dog-gets-high-chair-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA poorly dog with a rare medical condition can only eat out of a specially designed HIGH CHAIR. Buck, a -month-old Labrador, suffers from megaesophagus - which means he cannot eat food without being sick unless he is held in an upright position. So university boffins and an animal charity teamed up to create the unique contraption which holds the pooch in place so he can get down enough food. Buck currently weights just half of what he should and might have starved to death and not made it beyond his second birthdaythe high chair hadnt been invented. Buck was taken in by the charity Team Edward Labrador Rescue before his story was spotted by University of Nottingham vet and teaching associate, Emma Drinkall. Along with her partner Nick Rowan, a senior lecturer in product design and engineering at De Montford University, the couple designed and built the chair in just a day. The high chair has been designed so that Emma and Nick can continue to adapt it as Buck hopefully piles on the pounds. Buck has not regurgitated since using the chair and his carers have put him on a high calorie puppy food diet to help him improve his strength. Emma, from the University of Nottingham’s School of Veterinary Medicine and Science, said: “We saw the Buck’s story on social media, and I knew we just had to do somethinghe was going to have a chance. Luckily Nick and I have the combined expertise and experience to build the chair quickly. Heartwarming moment chimp saved from poachers hugs rescuer before being released There is currently no surgery available for dogs with this condition, and as Buck is already receiving the medications that can help, the one thing other thing that could help him keep his food down is gravity itself. Being upright while feeding will help the food drip through the sphincter that controls access to his stomach. Dogs with megaoesophagus are at risk of developing very serious chest infections which can prove fatal, because they can accidentally breathe in food particles when they regurgitate their food. We hope that by feeding Buck this way and stopping him from regurgitating we will minimise the risk of this additional complication developing. Wendy, Team Edward Labrador Rescue, David Bucks’ foster Dad, and Laura Buck’s Vet have all done an amazing job with Buck so far.” Nick said: “I’m just so pleased with how it fits, how comfortably he sits in it and how happy he is to be fed like this. He is the same width in his shoulders as our own  kilo Jack Russell, so without meeting Buck ourselves, we had to double check his measurements during the build – it just didn’t seem right for a big dog like a Labrador.” Cheeky dog caught sipping owners pint outside pub after checking coast is clearVet Laura Pearce, from the Lawrence Veterinary Centre in Eastwood, Notts., has been Buck’s vet since he was rescued by the charity. She said: “I am actually surprised that Buck has lived as long as he has with this condition. His oesophagus is abnormal in that it’s enlarged and has lost its tube-like state that pushes food through to the stomach. It means little of the food he eats actually makes it into his stomach for digestion, most gets stuck in pouches in the oesophagus or is regurgitated again.” Skeletal dog dumped by side of busy road was hours from deathBuck weighed only kg when he was taken in by the charity Team Edward Labrador Rescue which are based in Mansfield, Notts. Wendy Hopewell, who runs Team Edward, said: We were really shocked. story: NewsTiny fridge part blamed for sparking Grenfell Tower infernoThe wire in the Hotpoint fridge-freezer is believed by experts to have overheated on Grenfells th floor, killing ShareCommentsByMatthew Young:,  NOV NewsAn inquiry has revealed the relay compressor compartment recovered from the fridge freezer from Flat  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the burnt out fridge part that started the killer Grenfell Tower inferno, investigators believe. A tiny wire connector in this Hotpoint fridge-freezer relay compressor is likely to have overheated in flat  on the fourth floor, the blaze inquiry was told. Electrical fire expert Dr John Glover highlighted “poor crimp connection”, which made the wires unsafe by failing to keep them tightly gripped. He said: “The overheating of the crimp starts the fire. It overheats, it glows, it ignites.” The inquiry previously heard that shyflat owner Behailu Kebede saw that smoke “seemed to be coming from his Hotpoint fridge-freezer”, calling  at .am. The blaze, on June , , spread quickly across the  floors of the West London tower block, killing .  Cabbie Mr Kebede, then , was one of three living in the flat. Dr Glover, engineer atshy shyinvestigators Failure Electrical, said poor crimping showed up in CT scans. “I found voids in  cross-sections indicating the crimp was not nice and tight.”  In a report for the inquiry Dr Glover concluded: “The overheating connector in my opinion was the first event that started burning the insulation on the wires that led to a short circuit.” This year, consumers were advised to carry on using the Hotpoint FFB after it was assessed as posing a “low risk” in an independent investigation. story: NewsWoman who doctors thought was pregnant had kg cyst the weight of seven newbornsEXCLUSIVE: Keely Favell, , from Swansea, carried an oian cyst so big she had dficulty breathingShareCommentsByRobin Eveleigh:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsKeely, , had a five-hour op to remove the growth "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Keely Favell’s swollen tum drew questions about baby due dates, she spared everyone embarrassment by playing along.
